Award.AwardTitle: Single-Molecule Mechanochemical Sensing for Multiplexed Tasks
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) program of the Division of Chemistry at the National Science Foundation. Professor Hanbin Mao of Kent State University is developing new biosensing strategies that have high sensitivity to detect multiple chemical or biological targets simultaneously. Broader impacts are addressed through the development of integrated research-education projects to train high-school and college students. Many parts of research plans are modularly designed in to accommodate the tight schedules of high school and college students. This facilitates the participation of these students into the STEM fields.

This project employs individual macromolecules, such as DNA, as platforms for analyte sensing. Upon the binding of an analyte, the macromolecule changes its conformation, which is accompanied by a variation in mechanical properties, such as tension, due to the mechanochemical coupling. Using laser tweezers, the change in the mechanical property is monitored in real time, accomplishing the sensing without extra infrastructure used in a separate signal transduction unit. Since single-molecule templates are used, detection of individual molecules is the result. This represents the utmost sensitivity for biosensing. Compared to other single-molecule detection schemes such as fluorescence, the force signal employed in a mechanochemical sensor suffers little from environmental noise. In addition, the measurement of force does not require direct light excitation, which avoids photo-damage to the sensing template. All these facts render strong reliability and high sensitivity for this new sensing strategy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. The mechanochemical sensing platforms we developed for this NSF grant offered a transformative strategy to streamline traditional sensing schemes.  Upon ligand binding, a macromolecule (here we used DNA as an example) changed its conformation, which was accompanied by a variation in mechanical properties, such as tension or extension, due to the mechanochemical coupling.  Using laser tweezers, the change in the mechanical property was monitored in real time, accomplishing the sensing without extra infrastructure required for a separate signal transduction unit in conventional sensing.  Our new strategy exploited single-molecule templates, which empowered the detection of individual molecules, the utmost sensitivity for biosensing.  Compared to other single-molecule detections such as fluorescence, the force signal employed in a mechanochemical sensor had little environmental noise.  In addition, the measurement of force did not require light excitation directly, which avoided photo-damage to the sensing template.  All these rendered unprecedented reliability and sensitivity for the new sensing strategy.  Using this new sensing method, we demonstrated femtomolar detection limit of miRNA.  The sensing also showed multiplexing capability as demonstrated in the detection of multiple miRNA analytes.

During this grant period, we have published following papers and 1 patent.

Broader Impact. This NSF grant has allowed us to train four high school students: Andrew Tian, Rebecca Stayer, Serena Kaplan, and Bekarys Dukenbaev; seven undergrad students: Christian Beneze, Katia Ascencio, Tanner Wherley, Benjamin Wales-McGrath, Maggie Paul, Medelyn Kist, and Matt Sunthimer; seven graduate students: Shankar Mandal, Prakash Shrestha, Sangeetha Selvam, Mohammed Enamul Hoque, Sagun Jonchhe, Mohammad Akter Hossain, and Shankar Pandey; and one exchange student (Sheng Lin from Hongkong Baptist University). All high school students and most college students had no prior research experience before joining us.  The biosensing projects sponsored by NSF served a role to attract them to the STEM fields. For example, one of the high-school students is taking STEM courses through the College Credit Plus program at Kent State this semester (Fall, 2019). We anticipate the new mechanochemical sensing strategies will be instrumental to detect biomarkers for various diseases as well as toxic materials in environment. By applying a patent for this sensing technique developed during the project, it paves the way for the commercialization of the sensing method. Therefore, we hope it will not only advance the biosensing field, but also help the US economy in the long run.
